document.title: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops

B3CDEC3DBA864AC99EF4EE40B0BA1B4B.description: 1) At the time Jesus lived, the designation “brother and sister” also referred to cousins and sometimes even close neighbors.

EBDDF3DC986241B8BFBF168866C83A14.description: b. It is not clear who the “brothers and sisters” of Jesus are.

CDBE34E2ACE442ABA3CC2355CAFBB623.description: a. From the earliest days of the Church, Mary has been revered as ever-virgin; she was a virgin before Jesus’ birth and remained a virgin afterward.

594AE1183D1C417CA4A1724828E04569.description: 2. Questions about references in the Gospels to the brothers and sisters of Jesus.

A04E599CE02A4F6BBBDC4A2B35322386.description: 3) When Mary and the saints were on earth, they cooperated with God to do good for others; so now from their place in Heaven they continue to cooperate with God by doing good for others who are in need on earth and in Purgatory.

45450D47957C4987BF4BD17B69A3D627.description: 2) When people pray to the Blessed Mother they are asking her in turn to offer the same prayer for them to God.

5B2001C024FC49FCB859A7B2DA7B42FF.description: 1) Since Mary is already in Heaven, she will know better than we how to offer praise and prayer to God.

047D290D114744ACA1F7CDA9B6A904C7.description: c. Prayers to Mary are asking for her intercessory help.

7FBA3A5094474B48BF2110EB85757140.description: b. Mary does not have the power to answer prayers on her own; God alone has that power.

6EA31E1A5ADD4507979B5E7211787071.description: a. Catholics do not worship Mary; worship belongs to God alone. They venerate Mary and the saints.

1F5D8AFC50684EB89C85984ED41F46D5.description: 1. Questions about why Catholics pray to Mary.

523B20556772436B95BCB76C27B312F3.description: F. How do we as Catholics answer questions about the Blessed Virgin Mary and her role in the life and prayer of the Church (CCC, nos. 148, 484-511, 721-726, 773, 963-972, 829)?

8251A80A1D9D450C92F95B82EC53E6C4.description: 2. Christ has also given the Church a share in his own infallibility (CCC, nos. 889-892).

320AC6F3E4434D8981B7A668F6DED42D.description: c. Jesus Christ promised his Apostles that he would be with the Church until the end of time (Mt 28:20).

00B7B7817FEB41CFA2482C4FDE810E1B.description: b. Through the centuries, the popes and bishops, the successors of St. Peter and the Apostles, have carefully transmitted to the generations whom they shepherd the truths revealed and taught by Jesus Christ (CCC, nos. 96, 171, 173, 815).

E5B2382813894955A58804CD235517BA.description:
a. What was revealed in and through Jesus Christ
was entrusted to St. Peter and the Apostles,
who were taught directly by Jesus. They in
turn passed on those beliefs through those who
succeeded them (CCC, nos. 81, 84).

0157E262BB474A86830FD06BC72A8CA8.description: 1. We can be sure that what the Church teaches has come from God because of Apostolic Tradition and Apostolic Succession (CCC, nos. 888-892, 861- 862, 858-860).

72B4B3CAB3574712BE901885C0DF2EBD.description: E. There are some who dismiss God’s Revelation and say that the beliefs and doctrines taught by the Church have been made up by members of the Church. How can we be sure that what the Catholic Church teaches has come from God?

BBE7899F4EA846F6997C28542F94D3CD.description: 6. Jesus established his Church to help people find true happiness and joy (CCC, no. 1832).

71BF0E3712784D5CB178DC1C2AFF202A.description: 5. True joy is the mark of followers of Christ (Phil 4:4; CCC, no. 1832).

75C4C10C814A44B385D4637E91948D6C.description: 4. The blueprint for true discipleship and happiness is found in Christ’s teaching of the Beatitudes (Mt 5:2-10; CCC, nos. 1716-1718).

E26595581C0A44D8BB9331533F339C8D.description: 3. Jesus Christ taught us all he did so that we might share in his joy (Jn 15:11), which shows us again his desire for our happiness (CCC, nos. 736, 1832).

C1313EBBFAFB4B85BFE40F42EEAB85F8.description: 2. God sent his only Son, Jesus Christ, so that we might be saved (Jn 3:16); that confident hope is the cause for happiness in spite of suffering (CCC, nos. 599-605).

49DED2ED511C4BFA87545618F05CA194.description: 1. Yes. From the beginning of Creation, God has created us to be happy both in this world and in the next and has shown us the ways to be truly happy. Unhappiness was caused by people themselves when they did not or would not listen to him (CCC, nos. 374-379).

0445D8730AD84584AC17965758F3F496.description: D. Does God really want us to be happy?

21C645C01F55490094C20CC36015C09D.description: 7. Natural disasters can be understood in part as a result of Original Sin (CCC, no. 400) and also because the world is in a state of journeying toward ultimate perfection (CCC, no. 310); they are not signs of God’s displeasure or punishment.

01207940612F4F499E08AC0A49646C7B.description: 6. We need to remember that God always wants what is best for us (CCC, nos. 374-379).

75663B5F78D74C878BCAB18553717E64.description: 5. The Scriptures try to help us understand suffering: the psalms, the story of Job, and the prophets offer insights and consolation. In particular, the Resurrection of Jesus can help us see beyond suffering to hope and to eternal life (CCC, nos. 638-655).

CA407011D871480EBBE6DDBDAE0D3E18.description:
4. The Passion and Death of Jesus can help us to see
beyond suffering and remind us that God is present
with us in our suffering, pain, and death; our own
personal suffering when united to Jesus’ suffering
becomes redemptive for ourselves and others
(CCC, no. 1851).

C75208DCC4CD4E6AAEDD01394E9763F4.description: 3. Some suffering is the result of human sin and is not from God. It was God who gave us free will; sin is the result of the misuse of this gift (CCC, nos. 1849, 1852-1853).

FA246DE1D8CC464C912F13D978BD0DDF.description: 2. Evil is a reality and a mystery, that is, it is hard to understand the why of it (CCC, nos. 309-314). Some evil and suffering are a result of the work of the Devil or Satan (CCC, no. 395).

F0717F5063254094BBA747F2AF912C27.description: 1. Suffering that exists in the world is not something caused by God or sent by God; God only brings about what is good for he is goodness itself. When there is evil and suffering, God does not cause it, but sometimes he does permit it for reasons we cannot now know or understand (CCC, nos. 1500- 1501).

4FAAC13D6B5940A3ADBF2A0E73091F55.description: C. How can people say that God is good if suffering and evil are present in the world?

C0AF91459FD64452B4DA9AFC5A7F1F14.description: c. He tells us through the Church (CCC, nos. 785-786).

2383C5D0EC3149EAAD9E4A3FA9D4CB8B.description: b. He also tells us through the liturgy of the Church, speaking to us in the Scripture and giving himself to us in the sacraments, especially the Eucharist (CCC, nos. 1067, 1324-1327).

A34258C8CA584AF7A7D2BB5B36ABB66C.description: a. He tells us in Scripture, the living Word of God (CCC, nos. 80-82).

D7AC9C870E64463B97A1551D085EA2AD.description: 2. We also know of his love because he tells us of his loving plan to save us.

22B658464BDF467BB06A7D7A6B45561C.description: c. God helps us know and sense his love through the people and events of our lives (CCC, nos. 897-913, 1069).

92F28BDE5926480CB002753B71CE18F0.description: 3) God continually calls us to union with him in his Son through the Holy Spirit by means of a life of holiness (CCC, nos. 1091-1109).

FBB8307EDC6046EE9BE107DA1B1F491F.description: 2) Jesus lives now and establishes a relationship with each and every one of us, particularly through the sacramental life of the Church (CCC, nos. 662-664, 1084-1090).

45AC073833D24A3CAFD6F4228EC3AD65.description: 1) God sent his Son to redeem everyone from sin so that all can share a life of love eternally with him (Jn 3:16-17; CCC, nos. 599-605).

7EBFC770990042B49695F15671155F8F.description: b. The suffering and Death of Jesus Christ shows and proves that love (CCC, nos. 599-623).

D74FEEA86C8B412EBEA0936B5FCCE287.description: 2) God created human beings in his image and likeness with the ability to give and receive love (CCC, nos. 1700-1706).

7ADCE08F99E64417B8F82D191CEB54E5.description:
1) God created the world entirely out of love
and not out of necessity (CCC, no. 295).

54D0BC9198D64853868BD4847128EE69.description: a. He shows us his love in creation (CCC, no. 54).

483BDA04E53444E9AC314BB9DC1CD7A2.description: 1. We say God loves us deeply, even in the midst of suffering, because he reveals his love to us in many ways, especially in Christ’s taking our suffering upon himself for our sake (CCC, no. 1505).

E2C93DB28AB34C8585A333C671D78661.description: B. There are some who see human suffering and conclude that God does not care about us. Why do we say that he loves us deeply (CCC, nos. 1503-1505, 1681, 1808)?

4C239DD1DF7C4EA0B6A43D117F75CF2A.description: 4. We can also know God exists through faith. For those who do believe, through faith as well as prayer and grace, they can grow in the knowledge and experience of the reality of God and his existence (CCC, nos. 143, 153-159).

3823169D59A44E408B8A27C8C3A28D54.description: c. The faith of people we know today: the pope and the bishops in union with him; priests and deacons; parents, grandparents, and other family members; teachers and catechists; the witness of fellow Catholics as well as the witness of non-Catholic believers (CCC, nos. 85, 1655-1658).

624E0067E9C84C1480C2C47247266423.description: b. The testimony and witness of others who have gone before us: people whose stories appear in the Bible; Apostles, saints, and martyrs (CCC, nos. 823, 828, 857, 946, 1258, 2473).

65C5DD6841374DA7A32A9CB848C2379C.description: a. God’s Revelation comes down to us through Scripture and Tradition (CCC, nos. 50-53, 74-83).

2C29EE2B0C844D1AA916AA3C80BE61A2.description: 3. Reason and experience can also teach us to accept the word of other believers (CCC, no. 39).

B86FF2D6322D4906813C14D0D2D1E11E.description: c. The natural law written upon each person’s heart and the longing for God that each person has also point to God’s existence (CCC, nos. 1954-1960).

A661B9D47D3C4619BE348C716F592991.description: b. Creation did not happen by chance; throughout history the Church has taught that someone had to be behind it, and that someone is God (CCC, nos. 156, 295).

A25F42CA80424571803B8F1ABBCEF89F.description: a. The order and beauty of the natural world point to God as the origin and Creator of the universe (CCC, no. 295).

153728C19EAA41188DDF998C709F9966.description: 2. By looking around at creation, reason and experience can point to God’s existence (CCC, nos. 156-159).

C0D35A15AD944B05AE2342F5F2EE1793.description: 1. Even without the Bible and Divine Revelation, we can know God really exists through reason and through experience (CCC, nos. 36-39, 50, 156-159).

A2DBDC79F5B344C893383FA3D6D5012C.description: A. How can we know God really exists?

BEC8F007C2154BA39017D3FA46B0E1E2.description: b. Judgment: particular and final (CCC, nos. 677-679, 1021, 1038-1041).

9C3223CE10BB490DA39B22F2DEABC5A7.description: D. Jesus also tells us of the goal in this life and of the end of life.

9BB46B1408AA446682241A6EE84BF0FA.description: 5. Jesus sends out his disciples to evangelize (Lk 10: 1-20; Mt 28:16-20; CCC, nos. 861, 905).

8CCEE466E0E7453CAF6F1677CFC04FBF.description: 3) Jesus Christ intercedes for us (Jn 14:13, 16:24; CCC, nos. 2665-2669).

0CF2EEF33A4F473C9F38B0927EC25D32.description: 2) God is our Father, whom we approach through prayer (Mt 6:9-13; Lk 11:2-4; CCC, nos. 2759ff.).

1032E6F5D723455EA9CD8B0C46124959.description: 1) The Lord Jesus teaches us to approach prayer with humility and a sense of need (Lk 18:9-14).

38F997E03C8A4F7C92AEDDA87E927A30.description: b. Jesus Christ teaches us through prayer:

CC1128B522014CB9AD08E5EB0D34DBBD.description: 3) The Lord Jesus teaches the importance of perseverance in prayer (Lk 11:5-13, 18:1- 8; CCC, nos. 2729-2737, 2742-2745).

BEA9EB213744402781444140AE106208.description: 2) Jesus Christ teaches his Apostles and disciples to pray (Mt 7:7-11; CCC, no. 2609).

5ECAC1E3271C40C1B9E3A9E690F2176C.description: 1) Going off by himself to pray teaches us the importance of finding time for prayer (Mk 1:35, 6:46; Lk 5:16).

43A00DBE83064D559DB20CCF67E08968.description: a. In the Gospels, the Lord Jesus teaches us about prayer:

4284D2A356AB4680B54DFEF8C7909FDB.description: 4. He teaches us to pray and teaches us through prayer (CCC, nos. 2607-2615).

1710017D819743958F6261640E830F00.description: e. Teaching about the final judgment (Mt 25: 31-46; CCC, nos. 544, 1033, 1373, 2447, 2831).

8D3E42C2BD024BBE9870D424C9589D6A.description: d. The Two Great Commandments: love of God and love of neighbor (CCC, nos. 2083-2557).

226A650BF44245E59360ED194E35521A.description: c. “Good teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?” (Mk 10:17-22).

26019E8CCB964EF090C8808382D63DBE.description: b. Parables and other teaching of Jesus Christ (CCC, no. 546).

846795115C3E4BE09039EFFF92A8F085.description: a. Lessons from the Sermon on the Mount (Mt 5–7; CCC, nos. 1716-1724).

72CC79C5BDA847E9BCB5D1C04CFFB95A.description:
3. We are conformed to Christ and can grow in
holiness and goodness.

36D76930A67F4731A73BA80424B54589.description: 2. We become the free adopted children of the Father through Baptism (Gal 4; CCC, nos. 1265-1270).

6D69F5E16B384B809DD69E510A807F84.description: 1. By becoming man, and by his Death and Resurrection, Jesus Christ unites us to God (CCC, nos. 461-464).

1AD5BEFF3B1D4F9CBAD8BDB687E8742B.description: C. Jesus Christ reveals the Father to us, who we are, and our call to holiness.

AC9379BCAD36474486A3300C2048BC0C.description: 3. He teaches us how to be single-hearted in our desire for God, to offset the disordered affections and divided hearts with which we live (CCC, nos. 1716-1717).

C600AF598BA54524A032BC17858FC2CE.description: 2. He reveals the way to repentance and conversion, teaching us to leave sin behind and to live a new life in him; he gives us the spiritual power and grace to overcome evil; he also teaches us about God’s forgiveness (CCC, nos. 1847-1848).

E371F6EB5ADD48E6962223E877B209A6.description: 1. Jesus invites us to believe in him, to invite him into our hearts, and to follow him and his teaching as the path that leads to life, for he is “the way, the truth, and the life” and is worthy of our belief, adoration, and love (CCC, nos. 1741-1742).

23FA94E2D84E4C1EBCAF777E65F2E3CA.description: B. Jesus Christ redeems us and gives us his grace so that we can choose the good according to God’s will and resist sin and its effects (CCC, nos. 1705, 1708-1709).

9797E3B207964E84A9C75FFD73BAFA29.description: 4. God has entrusted his creation to us; we are stewards charged with procreating and protecting life and using the rest of creation respectfully (CCC, nos. 287, 354).

020DB163734C40A9B1E29BC12B1CF46F.description: 3. The Incarnation affirms that we are created as good, but in need of salvation, and are meant for eternal glory with God. The Incarnation also describes how God continues to work out our sanctification in the world, e.g., Church, sacraments, priesthood (CCC, nos. 461-469).

0E7F1614BB9E45D0948FAC06DC88DE2F.description: 2. To be fully human means to fully accept and become the person God created us to be, a human person endowed with special gifts which reflect God: immortality, intellect, free will, the ability to love (CCC, nos. 356-358, 1702-1706).

7D513283AF7C42CCA9FE220CF3AA837C.description: 1. God created the human person in his image and likeness; male and female he created them. This is why we must respect the dignity of all people (CCC, nos. 1700-1709).

778E6A57FB574EBD9A02F4964202A30C.description: A. Jesus embodies what has been revealed in and through creation.

EBF863D05911483DA41726A4A569447F.description: IV. Jesus Christ Teaches Us About Ourselves

E2BF81E3037F46489D7B659EB4787998.description: 4. The unity of the two natures in the one Person is called the “hypostatic union” (CCC, no. 468).

68CBC8E7D529424C8EBA52CA57847D32.description: b. Through things such as hunger and thirst in the desert, temptation by the Devil, grief at the death of Lazarus, agony in the Garden of Gethsemane, and his Death on the Cross, we know that he also experienced pain, suffering, and sorrow. In his human encounter with the sick and the outcast, he personified compassion (CCC, no. 538).

DD1579ABE19E494C8D2BF1F9E0918748.description: a. In his family life, his friendships, and his socialization with others we see him experience human joy and happiness and demonstrate human virtues.

BACC41E55B9D4605902C52C4EB0E7B37.description: 3. Jesus showed his humanity in every event of his human life (CCC, nos. 512-534):

4419D3B4A93843899FF349CA1B5ED433.description: 2. Jesus Christ took on a human nature. The eternal Son of God incarnate worked with human hands; he thought with a human mind. He acted with a human will, and with a human heart he loved. He was like us in all things except sin (CCC, no. 470). Man’s creator has become man (CCC, no. 526).

E4D2A0449519403987E41AF4FB865065.description: 1. Jesus Christ, a Divine Person, is truly the Son of God, who, without ceasing to be God and Lord, became man and our brother (CCC, no. 469).

C239FF6581694EA7A3E6E7CB2F4DE332.description: A. Jesus Christ is fully God and fully man (CCC, nos. 464-469).

AD9778B6F5974602AAA5E15D598BB3E4.description: III. The Mystery of the Incarnation

A624B7CD04414E0BB2F3332AFE8CA029.description: e. Mary is the first disciple.

774888D0D2874C95B126AEC593FB35C8.description: d. Mary is the Mother of the Church (CCC, no. 507).

528DC1480AC74DCC85D190C121610AEA.description: 1) Explain references in the Gospels to the brothers and sisters of Jesus (CCC, nos. 500-501).

1249A59B1F1049A78E1CDBE76F611627.description: b. An unparalleled recipient of God’s grace: Immaculate Conception; Assumption (CCC, nos. 490-494, 966).

D1651EA94CEC43F78ADF2F6089DB81EC.description: a. The Annunciation and Mary’s “yes” (CCC, nos. 484-487).

F721EA40ED3249E9B44E3DDF187BCDF9.description: 5. Unique role of Mary, the Mother of God.

0EFB767811054372B1695B6B3459FF83.description: b. Church teaching articulated to battle Gnosticism, Arianism, Nestorianism, Monophysitism (CCC, nos. 464-469).

D6112872D9664DCC9AB6A84E4D6AC938.description:
a. The struggles of the Church to maintain apostolic faith in light of Christological controversies and heresies (CCC, nos.
249-252).

645E0313D43C4D2E980163F9B101842B.description: 4. The development of Trinitarian theology in the early councils of the Church (CCC, nos. 245-248).

BB45CBCC6AFB496BB018C23006DE1239.description: c. Sanctifier of the Church and her members, e.g., gifts and fruits of the Holy Spirit (CCC, nos. 32, 731-741, 1830-1832).

50E1E83F065F418AA0EDE6AC7283CE39.description: b. Only fully revealed by Jesus (CCC, nos. 689-690, 727-730).

8AA8CBA72C3D4C8C8831AB10634C62CC.description: a. Eternally proceeding from the Father and the Son (CCC, no. 687).

93E966CA54B24898A99E0E7023B79425.description: 3. The Third Person of the Trinity: the Holy Spirit, the Lord and giver of life (CCC, nos. 243-248).

2ED435065DD44B9DA6EE931377977975.description: c. Son of Mary, true man; the perfection of who we are created to be (CCC, nos. 430, 456-469, 484-487).

3D0544FAA3164141BA017D7FA96C0682.description: b. Son of God, true God, consubstantial with the Father (CCC, no. 252).

FCCD8A03832A42F896BA5A26782EFA77.description: a. Jesus Christ is eternally begotten and incarnate in time (CCC, nos. 461, 422).

446D82240FBA44C4886EDC1AA6C84E99.description: 2. The Second Person of the Trinity: God the Son.

7126A4C4430A4231ACF37627FDB5358D.description: d. God the Father of mercy also cares for the unbaptized (CCC, nos. 1257, 1260-1261).

B3E3BDEF99BD4B6CB930CA702F4FD586.description: c. God is Father to all those baptized as his adopted sons and daughters through and in the Son (CCC, nos. 232-233, 249).

99D1E961FB524F60980C93DB1130C8A0.description: b. God is Father in relation to the Son from all eternity (CCC, no. 240).

574697B35D2844AB97001D9964DABCE5.description:
a. God the Father is the source of all that is,
visible and invisible.

E433311325684A6BAAFBBA7CF55E4CF0.description:
The First Person of the Trinity: God the Father
(CCC, nos. 238-242).

067E01431B70479FA0C30DF941100870.description: C. The Three Divine Persons of the Trinity.

FF270F754D3848D29C1E28D272E1FB8D.description:
b. The Divine Persons are distinct from one
another (CCC, no. 254).

1B78D59267924FA8B1BF9D2F485E3BBC.description: a. This is the central mystery of our faith (CCC, nos. 235-237).

6A6BA172F8B94590A653CDB359374F31.description: 1. God is Trinity: one in three Divine Persons (CCC, no. 234).

D2C23EFFF96E4F12929E19F473EB698E.description: B. The Revelation of Jesus about God (Jn 14:9).

45D44E9DA6464E5B92E4F21E107F1A86.description: c. All events of Christ’s life are worthy of reflection and imitation (see Gospel accounts).

24785A80BA8C48CF80D72AE103861DA8.description: b. Christ continues his presence in the world through the Church (CCC, nos. 732, 737-739, 747).

8EBFAE54E6654ED4A7E3A464A0CDA443.description: a. Jesus Christ is the Logos, the Word of God, the fulfillment of God’s promise to Adam and Eve and to the people of ancient Israel (CCC, nos. 761-762).

D702492CF90D4FEAA7E25E9587A0E0A6.description: 1. Mystery of the Incarnation: Emmanuel (God-iswith-us) (Jn 3:16-17; CCC, no. 484).

01837C1320944606B795F4E1DAD169DA.description: A. Son of God from all eternity and Son of Mary from the moment of the Incarnation (CCC, nos. 486, 496, 487, 501, 721-730).

29DE44C7C6A2419BA829E9D4F94252F9.description: d. The Magisterium guards and hands on the deposit of faith and is entrusted with the authentic interpretation of Revelation (CCC, nos. 880-896).

B6738C398E6B41AC980FF56E51C098EA.description: c. The Church is a unity of one faith in one Lord through one Baptism (CCC, nos. 813-16).

FAB7B1696D664CFA83CF82C507BCF670.description: b. Church is the Body of Christ in the world.

2C9EB2EFF69D49BA9B1AA91A7B0C24B5.description: a. The Church was founded by Jesus Christ (CCC, nos. 811-812).

8DAF7E0C9A3948BD87DC0DFAF56A792B.description: 4. The fullness of Revelation is reflected in the life and teaching of the Catholic Church (CCC, nos. 748-870).

9D757C3994A24103910C6B58BC41864D.description: b. Faith is different from religion.

6AC83C043A4E4165B572272559CEB11B.description: a. Religion refers to a set of beliefs and practices followed by those committed to the service and worship of God.

D6614E9525444A01BD7BB13031CC9261.description:
3. The relationship between faith and religion (CCC,
nos. 2084, 2135).

4DE6007AC240485FB7821E8E2E709DC8.description: c. This faith has practical implications for daily life and one’s relationship with Christ (CCC, no. 908). d. Involves active participation in the Church community and working to spread the faith by word and example.

90E5E5ECA4BB4F50A3D171DF8002858C.description: b. Willingness to believe and trust in what Jesus has taught us about the Triune God, about ourselves, and about how to live (CCC, nos. 915, 1693, 1816, 1823, 1986, 2262, 2347, 2427, 2466, 2612).

546A0AAEC2194F6C959145894DDBE01D.description: a. Recognition and acceptance of him as the Son of God who died to save us from our sins (CCC, no. 1248).

BF69513016FD40A4918BAE3FBCC4C12C.description: 2. Faith in Jesus Christ leads to discipleship (CCC, nos. 520, 546, 562, 654, 1533).

D28ED035807246A38B4E480E732A446F.description: c. Relationship with God: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit (CCC, nos. 150-152).
